issues.description: The problem statement explicitly instructs students to "Initialize the ArrayList in a constructor with no arguments" for Farm, and the template/Main usage expects creating a Farm with new Farm(). However, the solution's Farm class only provides a constructor with an int parameter (public Farm(int initialCapacity)) and does not provide a no-argument constructor. This constructor-parameter mismatch contradicts the exercise instructions and the template's example usage, and would confuse students or cause compilation/usage issues if code (or tests) assume a no-arg constructor.
issues.suggested_fix: Provide a no-argument constructor for Farm that initializes the animals ArrayList (e.g. public Farm() { this.animals = new ArrayList<>(); }). Alternatively, keep the parameterized constructor but also add a no-arg constructor (possibly delegating to the parameterized one). This will align the solution with the problem statement and the template/Main usage.

issues.description: The problem statement and template expect a no-argument Farm constructor (the instructions explicitly say to "Initialize the ArrayList in a constructor with no arguments" and the template Main instantiates Farm with new Farm()). The solution repository instead provides only a Farm(int initialCapacity) constructor and no no-arg constructor. This API mismatch will confuse students: they are instructed and shown (in the template) to use Farm(), but the reference solution does not provide that constructor, causing compilation errors or extra, unnecessary cognitive load to reconcile the difference.
issues.suggested_fix: Provide a no-argument constructor in the solution Farm class that initializes the animals ArrayList (e.g. public Farm() { this.animals = new ArrayList<>(); } ), or add a no-arg constructor that delegates to the existing constructor (e.g. public Farm() { this(10); } ). Keep the existing Farm(int) overload if desired. This restores direct alignment with the problem text and the template usage (new Farm()).
